While entertaining, this video is very misleading. A large fraction of research done in physical science and engineering is fact-based and reproducible. It is true, many are trivial, redundant or not helpful. But there are many practitioners in every subfield in these areas who are very happy to prove someone else wrong - especially if it conflicts with their own published work. Overstatements made in this video gain eyeballs, but lead to loss of credibility of results from fields that actually produce provable results. Of course, there are a few exceptions - but those that are false (cold fusion, for example) are eventually proven false and promoters lose credibility. In this area there is a huge penalty for being wrong about a major finding without an excellent reason. The fact that these fields are soundly based has been evident since the industrial revolution. Even Newton, who was wrong about gravity, gave very useful equations for computing physical behavior.

Apart from and besides all kinds of poorly conducted experiments and malevolent data manipulation, both with the aim of publication, there is the 'curse' of the Gaußian probability distribution. Some academics seem to think that every dataset out there is 'properly' normally distributed; even in cases about which is known that they're not (for instance in distributions with a high degree of skewness ), a normal distribution is oftenly assumed 'for clarity'.
A Gaußian can, in some cases, indeed be applied as an approximation but this needs to be properly verified and not assumed out of the blue.

Example: if a discrete stochast has but a few possible outcomes, a normal approximation will not hold due to its continuous characteristics; a Poisson-distribution may be normally approximated if it applies to a wide set of stochastic values and a large dataset that is not too skew (however, there is something that is called 'skew normal', people should use it if they do want to approximate).

If the kurtosis is too large, like in the case of a Laplacian, a Gaußian approximation is off in almost every case. The fact that normally distributed variables should be able to assume negative values also seems to be the origin of 'serious difficulties' .... >sigh<

Statistics is a very, VERY powerful analysis tool but if and only if it is indeed applied without a priori bias; whenever such a bias is introduced, the outcome starts to tend towards nonsense.
In research there is no such thing as 'the proper answer', if that were the case then there is no reason to start a research in the first place.

Part of the problem is reliance on "Statistical Significance" which only tells you if there is a difference in the data. But you already know this by looking. It doesn't tell you if the same difference will occur in future data which is precisely what most people are asking when applying "Statistical Significance".

Also there is this "p-value" thing. P-values are NOT probabilities. It's called a "p-value" for a reason: frequentists can't assign probabilities to non-observables. Calling the measure "p-value" then pretending it's a probability is a backdoor end-around to this restriction. The p-value measure comes about by assuming if you repeated the experiment an infinite number of times AND the results are normally distributed THEN the value you get will be observed N times. However, (1) you can't get infinite repetitions; (2) the normal distribution is a mathematical fiction which can never be observed in the real world; and (3) even if you accept that you can get distributions close enough to this fiction (whatever that means), it's unlikely the experiment will be repeated 10 times let alone a very large number of times so there is no basis for assuming the result distributions are close to normal.

When used in the Hypothesis Test, p-value only tells you how well the parameters of your model fit the data at-hand and tell you nothing about how the model will perform with future data. You can try using a leave-N out approach but that will not eliminate any bias in the data at-hand.

The only way to assess a model is to replicate it using different data. Then, if you keep getting the same parameters, you might be on to something.

"scientific method is way more reliable than any other way of knowing that we have"

Not quite. The scientific method follows from axioms of probability so it should work and indeed we observe it working, but ultimately it's only a special case and there are other ways of knowing (all other ways of knowing that follow from probability axioms). Scientists themselves routinely flout the scientific method in certain situations and in many of these cases they are entirely correct to do so! Say, the first time Newtonian physics made a new prediction was the location of as-of-yet undiscovered Neptune: lack of new predictions is in terrible contradiction of the scientific method as currently understood - for this reason it's not even properly falsifiable - but people (correctly) accepted his theories. The exact same could be said about Darwin-Wallace theory of evolution for example: no testable predictions (in contrast to modern mathematically robust theory of evolution that does). Or, most scientists today refuse to strongly believe in ESP almost no matter how many and how rigorous experiments parapsychology manages to produce following the common practices of the scientific method (they could even be viewed as pioneers of rigor, following demands of sceptics).

The reasons you can do this are all the other ways of knowing following from axioms of probability. Newton's theory of gravity didn't make any new predictions for the longest time but it was ELEGANT, capable of explaining the known observations at least as well as any other known explanation, but can be presented in a equation of just several terms. People at the time didn't know off Kolmogorov complexity or Solomonoff's induction, but they intuitively surmised the simplicity of his theory was a great merit of Newton's. Conversely, people now have (thanks to our scientific worldview) formed a very strong prior against the existence of ESP: the required physical mechanisms seem implausible, if you input the estimated fitness advantage to population genetics equations the chance of fixation is ~0, nobody has managed to purposefully use ESP in presence of a magician... The studies could have p=.0000000000000001 and due to inherent improbability of the phenomenon, we (with almost utter certainty correctly) conclude the result is more likely a result of deliberate deception, flaws in the study, or even us misunderstanding the paper, rather than any actual ESP being observed.

And these ways of knowing aren't limited to believing Newtonian gravity or disbelieving ESP. A perfectly rational agent could run circles around science, even idealized science with no p-hacking or publication bias (they'd still need to perform experiments and run analyses of course, but could to large extent cut ahead of the scientific process and insitutions), and in practice very boundedly rational humans can have a pretty good batting average in deciding what purported science to believe. So it's not that science is the best way of knowing, it's the best SYSTEMATIC way of knowing given very bounded rationality of humans, placing limits on how much one making the claim can massage the results, and that performs ON AVERAGE better than other methods: people aren't acting in full accordance with the scientific method when they say "I disbelieve this ESP study with p=.000001 and no replication-study that seems to falsify it", but the method of following where your personal rationality leads you to also produces beliefs such as "Earth is flat" or "modern CRT monitors are a cancer risk worth being concerned about".

It's just not true that science is the most reliable way of knowing, i.e., justifying that a particular conclusion is true. It's true in many cases, but not true in others, i.e., science can in many cases, through experimentation for example, give us a more certainty than other methods depending on the question at hand. However, if I'm reasoning using a deductive argument, providing it's sound, then the conclusion follows with absolute necessity, no amount of science is going to increase the certainty of the argument. Moreover, if I'm using an inductive argument, and the certainty of my conclusion is very high, then it may be insignificant in terms of certainty, whatever science concludes. There are also other methods of justifying a conclusion, for example, I make the claim that the orange juice is sweet, and you ask, "How do you know?" - I respond, "Because I tasted it," so I know based on sensory experience. Am I certain? Yes. I don't need some scientist to verify that the orange juice is sweet to know it's sweet. Moreover, much of what we know is based on sensory experience, we use it all the time. Can science increase our certainty in some cases? Yes. But in many cases our certainty is so high that it would be insignificant in terms of certainty to have science verify my conclusion. There are also other methods of justifying a conclusion, including testimonial evidence (which is one of the weakest justifications, but under the right conditions testimonial evidence can be very strong), which we use all the time. Much of what we learn comes in the form of testimony, even this video was in the form of testimony. Most of us aren't able to conduct experiments ourselves, so we take the word of others, viz., testimony. Much of what I'm talking about has to do with epistemology (the study of knowing), and it seems that many people don't have a good grasp of this subject, including some scientists.

This is a more profound problem, right now, still unsolved in reinforcement learning: reward hacking. It happens on school tests, on job interviews, on dating, almost everything where we want something, there is a competition, and the agents (us) have incentives to optimize the reward function (publication, grades, relationship).

How to design a reward framework where hacking isn't possible, that is also fair? (we can make opaque metrics and use intrinsic metrics like curiosity to hinder the hacking, but the agent finds a way). This is also a problem in games, where gamers optimize the fun out of games, and a problem on capitalism itself, when companies play dirty to get more market share. Also, a problem with elections, where manipulating and playing dirty is rewarding.

The point is, this isn't human nature, this is actually expected from any sufficiently intelligent agent. A reinforcement learning agent can learn to exploit a glitch in the simulation engine to get a higher score. The point is, if we act greedy and there is at least a small chance of trying most things (an epsilon soft policy) then we will find optimal behavior at some point, which is, behavior that maximizes the reward received. This can be exploiting a loophole or changing the reward function altogether! Is there a general way to formulate a Markov decision process where the agent will not exploit false positive reward signals, for which it will lead to higher reward but not optimal behavior? Even more, is there a general method to specify a reward in which the agent will follow the desired behavior, or at least bounds around this specification? We don't know yet. The problem intuitively seems undecidable to me, but no proof so far of either case. If it's truly undecidable, then there may be no hope in ever solving completely all these problems, ever.

They can tell whatever story they want to tell about how they collected and analyzed their data and there's almost no way to verify it. A researcher could look through 500 pages worth of interview data, for example, and only pull quotes from 2 pages worth of carefully selected text to craft an article. Essentially, a dishonest qualitative researcher can produce any type of conclusions they want to and even honest qualitative researchers doing the best job they can are frequently just publishing the point of view their favorite theory is already driving at. As a researcher, reviewer, sometimes editor, and tenured prof, two comments; 1) describing the p =.05 as 'arbitrary' is technically true (using a nice round number such as .05 is arbitrary), but it's conceptually false. It is based on balancing type I error (false positives - what p measures) with type II error (false negatives - measured by power or beta). If you decrease type I error to be more certain, you automatically increase type II error, sometimes massively. In typical psych experiments the probability of a type II error -- using p < .05 as a cut-off (or "alpha") -- is generally around 15% - if you decrease the acceptable p-value, the probability of type II error will increase far beyond 15% - also not good. You can only trade off one kind of error for another - you cannot get rid of the possibility of error. Fisher was a lot smarter than you give him credit for. He was wicked smart.
2) The underlying problem is the shift since the 1970s in the measurement of researchers' productivity by administrators to simply counting the number of papers published. Whereas 40 years ago, publishing 2 papers a year meant you were a highly productive researcher -- today that level of publishing will get you fired for non-performance. If you increase the required output, the quality of each individual paper will of necessity suffer you just don't have time. The researchers aren't the source of this problem - the administration is. The underlying problem is the takeover of university administrations by "managers" instead of professors - they were trained to count units of output as measures of productivity, so that is what they do.
Over that time frame the number of profs at most universities in the US has stayed the same, but the number of administrators has doubled and in some cases trebled -- paying for those administrators is the cause of the massive rise in college tuition -- it is emphatically NOT going to professors, whose salaries have stagnated since the 80s, like most peoples'.

P-hacking is just the start of it. It could be reduced a great deal if scientists had better education in statistics and data analysis. Amazingly, very few do. Very few understand the assumptions that go into calculating a p value, or know what a chi-square statistic is, or understand that not all distributions are Gaussian so your p-value may be a massive underestimate, or understand the role of correlations, etc. But that wouldn't eliminate the many other problems that come, at least in part, from journals' overwhelming profit motive and from researchers' incessant pressure to publish, no matter what. As others have said, you get the behavior you incentivize.

I've personally observed all of the following:
-Guest authorships for people who had little or nothing to do with the research (I suspect a majority of papers have this in some fields)
-Scientists who were instrumental in designing/conceiving the experiment getting cut out so that the remaining authors can get larger shares of the credit (this has been done to me and to many of my colleagues many, many times; these days, I expect it.)
-Big-name authors being able to push an article through peer review despite an unambiguous rejection by a reviewer or even multiple reviewers (again, on multiple occasions; the problem seems to be worse with bigger-name journals)
-High-quality, well-supported research results being considered unpublishable just because a journal editor doesn't think it's going to sell a lot of subscriptions (this is normal; it happens to probably more than half of journal submissions; remember that a journal's job is not to promote science but to make money)
-Papers getting published in respectable journals with such absurdly obvious basic flaws that an undergrad should be able to immediately see why they're bogus (we're talking perpetual motion type stuff; just ridiculously silly ideas)
-Big-name professors attaching themselves to already-successful projects and then taking credit for them, using their platform to convince the world that they invented the thing when they don't really even know how it works
-Scientific conferences at vacation resorts where everyone is an invited speaker but no one has their fees covered, i.e. just blatantly selling invited speakerships to bogus conferences in league with resorts (and plenty of scientists willing to pay to play that game, using taxpayer money)

All this in a world where, at least for technical articles, Wikipedia is a more reliable source than Science or Nature. Getting published in a big-name journal means that it's flashy, not that it's likely to be true.

In a world with millions of scientists, the incentive structure practically guarantees this behavior. The system is deeply, deeply flawed.

And yet it still seems to kind of work. On the whole, the scientific enterprise shambles towards the truth, 100 steps forward, 99 steps back. There are many problems with the original paper and, as a result, with this video. I suggest everyone go and read Ioannidis' original paper and then read the brilliant response paper by Goodman and Greenland (2007), which highlights the logical and mathematical errors made by Ioannidis. Ioannidis then responded to that paper but I do not find his follow up to be convincing.

The first issue with this video is the misunderstanding of p-values. "How much of the published research literature is false? The intuitive answer seems to be 5%." No. This would only be true if the average p-value of all research results was 0.05. In reality, most published research finds p-values much lower than 0.05. In fact, a p-value of 0.05 should only be taken at face value if the p-value is not controversial... If you had a study that found peaches cure cancer and your relevant p-value was 0.049, this would warrant close scrutiny.

Another issue is that this video is misleading about what replication entails. You seem to think that replication is something that is done after a study is published, by a different set of researchers. This definitely can be the case, but a robust study has replication built into it. This is especially true for medical research. You study multiple samples and compare the results with eachother. This is replication. Obviously, replication built into a study might fall victim to biases so efforts are usually taken to remove bias.

Ioannidis' paper makes several bizarre and illogical claims. Ioannidis claims that the more an area is studied, the higher the proportion of false results are found. Interesting piece. I think the first take away should be that just because something is published, doesn't mean it's true. It means it has met the criteria for publication. Ignoring outright fraud, which does happen, and can be driven by the need to publish, the peer review process is a quality control effort. You read the manuscript, read its references, look at the rest of the literature to see if others have already published it, or if there are other references that cast doubt on the result. You, as a peer reviewer, exercise your own expertise to make a judgment about the manuscript. If you accept for publication, you are saying that it is new, that the methods used are sound, that there is actual insight, and that it addresses a problem important enough to generate a good audience. You are not saying that the paper is, without doubt, true.  So, if you are reading a published paper, you should be looking at the rest of the literature as well.

I'm an MD and while we studied all these criteria for statistical analysis, unbiased scientific study design, etc., this particular phenomenon was never mentioned (that I recall) at my medical school. Interestingly, it corresponds to a concept we use in evaluating testing modalities called Positive Predictive Value, meaning the likelihood that if someone tests positive for a disease that they actually have that disease. Unlike Sensitivity and Specificity (the false positive and false negative rates), which remain the same for a given test regardless of disease prevalence, the PPV is hugely influenced by the prevalence of a disease in a population. This corresponds very closely with your idea that the validity of a study with a statistically significant difference with p<0.05 decreases with an increasing number and ratio of studies investigating untrue hypotheses.

Excellent video. I once constructed an "experiment" for a stats class using winning lottery number combinations, gleaned from reported winners of previous contests in our state. The purpose of the "experiment" was to show how easily we could manipulate the outcome, and create false conclusions ("lucky numbers," so to speak), simply by adjusting the sample size. By increasing the sample size, we obviously reached the conclusion that the chance of any number being chosen was equal to that for all other numbers -- i.e. they are random. Despite this, I was amazed to find that some of my students really believed it was possible to predict future winners based on past results, even after we completed the project. The will to believe there must be some sort of hidden relationship between the various numbers occasionally overwhelmed reason -- which suggests something about our willingness to believe objectively foolish propositions ... and conspiracy theories.

We need to fundamentally rethink the idea of papers as a monolithic chunk of work to be done by a single team. Pre-publishing methods, reporting null findings, and replication studies all need to be parts of the knowledge discovery process.

We no longer live in an era where papers must be static. We need to adapt to that change.

Speaking as an actual scientist, this video is nonsense. The title is pure click-bait, and the message is a misunderstanding of the scientific method based on a fairly silly paper.

1. True science uses empirical observations to explain and predict phenomena. That is, given a correct method for observation, you can evaluate and correct a hypothesis. After enough iterations, that hypothesis will converge to something of value - presto.

2. Psychology is generally not an empirical science in the usual sense, and medical science often has to rely on very poor statistics. These fields are indeed so methodologically challenging that many published papers cannot be reproduced, and perhaps should be retracted. It is therefore dishonest to lump these disciplines in with 'science' in general. However, if you think that in any way detracts from the value they provide, you are delusional.

3. The hard sciences, like the particle physics you mention, generally do not suffer from such methodological challenges. That doesn't make their hypotheses automatically correct, however. Hypotheses evolve on the back of methodologically solid, published observations. In a very important sense, as long as you're thorough and honest, publishing the 'wrong' idea is every bit as important as publishing the 'right' idea. Once the 'right' idea in is reached in a field, the science of that field is often over and done with.

There's also one other thing to consider. Unless a research paper is done with the intention of proving a hypothesis/theory, and with a firm criteria for how to do that, which makes logical sense, it's not technically part of the scientific method. It's required for the scientific method, but is not part of it. This is because statistics are not science; they're a form of logical inference grounded in what's called "abductive reasoning." In this form of reasoning, you observe data, to seek the simplest and most likely explanation, which is a logical process, not a scientific one, and because it's not deductive in nature, the conclusion isn't guaranteed to be true, even if the premises are true.

In practice, abductive reasoning is used mainly to recognize trends and patterns in the world, so that we can form hypotheses, to try to explain those patterns. In short, they come before the first step of the scientific method; the forming of a hypothesis. There's a big difference between conducting a specific experiment, designed to prove whether a specific theory is true or false, and taking in a large amount of data, to determine where the majority of the evidence in a certain group points. The first one is science, and the second is not.

The media, of course, doesn't recognize these subtle distinctions, so they jump on anything that sounds shocking, and in the process, spread misinformation everywhere about what kinds of things are "proven" by "science," and what kinds of things aren't.

One solution to the p hacking problem would be to set the overall significance of the study to less than 0.05 or 0.01.
That is, the combined probability of the various outcomes should be below that value. the p value per hypothesis (ph) can then be calculated from the total p (pt) from the formula:
pt = 1 - (1-ph)^n
Where n is the total number of hypotheses tested.
Here, the maximum value of ph should be such that pt is smaller than the set limit.

The answer to the question posed in the video title is "it strongly depends on the specific field," and it's very disingenuous -- especially on an otherwise high-quality channel such as this one -- for you to sweep that under the rug.

There's simply no getting around the fact that this issue (i.e., p-hacking and a general lack of reproducibility) is overwhelmingly limited to the "soft" sciences. In the video, you explicitly called out psychology, neuroscience, and medicine, but you then followed this up with a token example from physics in an effort to show that this issue can affect the rigorous sciences as well. And that's true, in the sense that there will be the occasional biased or flat-out wrong paper published in the hard sciences. But the difference is that, in the hard sciences, such flawed findings are typically rooted out very quickly and very publicly. The simple reason for this is that these fields are cumulative -- i.e., subsequent results build on previous ones -- and so a missing foundation quickly becomes very evident as soon as someone tries to build upon it. To take your example, the "detection" of the theta+ pentaquark was published in 2003, and by 2006 the field of physics had thoroughly debunked the finding and publicly admitted as much in the Review of Particle Physics that year. Such rapid and unflinching correction is the hallmark of good science, and it's tragic that you lump this in with the truly problematic p-hacking that occurs in less rigorous fields.

Don't get me wrong -- there is a very real problem occurring in some fields of science, and it's good for that problem to be brought to light. But videos (or articles) like this one, which fail to make any real distinction between well-behaved and poorly-behaved fields of science, end up doing all of science a huge disservice. If the public is broadly skeptical of all scientific results (and who wouldn't be, after you essentially claimed that ~50% of the literature is wrong?) rather than having their skepticism directed at the appropriate culprits, then it should come as no surprise that distrust of science and scientists is at an all-time high. The other issue I have yet to see widely spoken of is that, if you fix the 'small sample size' problem with a large sample size, your selection criteria must be sufficiently broad to allow you to select such samples.

The results, if well replicated, will effectively give you an average across the population meeting that selection criteria, effectively averaging away individual differences between experimental subjects. The problem arises when trying to determine how relevant this is to a given individual.

You get something which is roughly explained as:

if I start with an initial selection criteria A(x), and some individual a0 matching this criteria (so an individual x meets the selection criteria for being a subject of a trial if and only if A(x) holds, and A(a0) holds), and create an ordered family of additional selection criteria B_i(x) such sets { x: A(x) and B_i(x) for i in I } where I selects some of those additional criteria, and so that if we select all of those criteria, we are guaranteed that only the particular individual we started with, a0, satisfies all of them.

Now consider hypothetical studies done for all such selection criteria, and how the probabilities will change as we 'limit towards a0' in the sense that if we are interested in the probability of some property P(X) such as 'treatment R works for X', then what happens in the sequence P(X), P(X given A(X)), P(X given A(X) and B_0(X)), P(X given A(X), B_0(X) and B_1(X)), and so on. This represents the ability of a clinical to do further tests or get more data about a patient they are dealing with. If the probability that 'treatment R works for X' changes significantly as we add more specifics about a given patient, then the original trial selecting only for people for whom A(x) holds, becomes less and less relevant. However, too many naively assume implicitly that this never occurs when deciding to use a 'treatment supported by clinical trial research'.

The technical term here is 'omitted covariates', and it is rare to see this issue properly treated in areas like medical research. Rather studies assume it away by averaging over large samples, and others then forget to put them back before thinking through clinical decisions.

This is why I've more or less stopped caring about statistics and papers as a primary argument, and started caring more about the underlying logic in a hypothesis.
If a hypothesis seems unbelievable to begin with, it's very likely that anything supporting it is the result of shoddy work. However, if the argument a hypothesis makes is rock-solid, makes complete sense, and has no logical fallacies, it's usually a safe bet to assume it's true until overwhelming evidence proves otherwise.
That's a big problem I've seen in the soft sciences, especially psychology- there have been so many awful studies based on proving emotional assumptions that it's pretty much impossible to actually find out the truth by looking at the "evidence". What seems to work out much better is simply trying to reason out basic ideas about how people think, and then using those assumptions until there's a big reason not to.
For example, it's obvious and reasonable to assume that people build negative and positive associations between themselves and other things, and this is what causes things like phobias, anxiety, and fetishes. It then seems obvious that with controlled exposures, those abnormal associations can be treated and returned to normal. It makes perfect sense, works with what we've all experienced, and has had a long history of being an accurate hypothesis. That's not to say that it could be disproven, but it's a lot more believable than most of the garbage that fills psychological/sociological/etc. journals.

p-values are more complicated than that. In physics, chemistry, and other fields where datasets allow for cutoffs of p=0.05 or p=0.01 or something, sure--a particle physicist that sets a lower bar (or a parapsychologist) is going to run into trouble quite quickly. An astronomer describing a nova or a paleontologist describing an ancient ecosystem, on the other hand, can--and frequently do--publish with a single datum.

I've often wanted to start a peer-reviewed journal specifically for failed results--"We tried this, it didn't work." I've seen the danger of not publishing such results. People spend YEARS replicating experiments that were shown to not be effective, or testing hypotheses disproven, a generation or more ago. Because we don't publish this stuff, that information is lost very quickly. You only find out about it if your circle of contacts overlaps the circle of contacts of the person who did the original failed experiment.

All that said.....These complaints are mostly that science doesn't work fast enough. Every one of these flaws was discovered by science, via the self-correcting processes built into the activity. What most people forget (even scientists who should know better) is that there are TWO rounds of peer review any paper goes through. The first is the formal peer review prior to publication,the one everyone talks about. The second is less formal, and never ends: it is the review of the paper by scientists as they use it. Every scientist who builds an experiment based on the data in that paper is in fact reviewing it. This second review takes longer, and as I said never ends; I've referenced Linnaeus' work. And eventually it will almost certainly find the flaws.

If we'd abandon Publish or Perish it would help. The idea that only folks with consistent high volumes of high quality publications are worth hiring in a university is strangling science, because we can't publish negative results and many are forced to ignore long-term projects in favor of short-term studies that net more publications. If someone wanted to come up with a way to kill science without openly killing it, this would be one of the best options (I'm not saying there's a conspiracy, just saying it's effective).

I'm a graduate student currently working towards an academic career. I have been told by several profs in my field including my advisor that if I want to get a faculty job at a good institution after finishing my phd, I need to have at least 8-9 papers in my CV with at least 2-3 in a high impact journal. The reason is, of course, the sheer amount of competition; there are huge numbers of applicants and very few open positions. When hiring researchers, universities look at their previous research i.e., papers - and people can count much better than they can read. As a grad student, you can dedicate your 4-6 years to one fundamental problem, work on it rigorously, and if things work out end up publishing one or two papers with a huge impact on the field. But when you then go looking for jobs, you'll have trouble because people can count better than they can read. They'll say "Oh this guy only has 2 papers but this other guy has 15, let's hire the other guy." I know a lot of people in this situation - extremely bright grad students who cannot get faculty positions or even decent postdocs because they don't have enough papers in their CV. Many grad students who intend to stay in academia are aware of this, and there is no way you can publish at least 8 papers in 4-6 years without sacrificing rigor and/or reproducibility.

There is another interesting problem with p-values. Say a publication proposes a novel, unexpected hypothesis, e.g. in biological sciences. The said mechanism is demonstrated by 6 experiments, each proving an essential sub-hypothesis of the whole story with statistical significance of p=0.05. The likelihood that all are true is 0.95^6, which is just 73%.

There is 27% probability the whole story is wrong.

Most high-impact papers in biology consist of 5-10 figures with panels from a to f plus numerous supplementary figures.

Taking that one cherry picked example from particle physics and acting like the situation in physics is just as bad as in psychology is pretty disingenuous. Published results in most sub-fields of physics are MUCH more reliable and reproducible than social sciences, etc. And extraordinary results are met with massive skepticism and scrutiny, see for instance the neutrinos travelling faster than light result from a couple years ago.

Here's another example of how the level of confidence in published research is simply not comparable when considering hard sciences and social sciences; just a couple months ago when LIGO released the second round of results they weren't willing to classify one of the events as a black hole merger because it was only at the 4 sigma confidence level - in a social science a result that significant would be practically canon instantly.

P-values have an inherent problem, even if everything is done correctly. They measure the strength of your evidence rather than the likelihood that you're right. Even when an experiment is done properly, a p-value of less than 0.05 does not mean you have a greater than 95% chance of being correct. This xkcd comic shows it simply: https://xkcd.com/1132/. The strength of your evidence is 1/36 (35:1 in favor of the sun exploding), but you have to consider the prior improbability of the sun exploding. The odds the the dice caused the positive result is 1/36, which is low. But what's the probability that the explosion of the sun caused the positive result? Far lower. As we all know, extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. That is to say, the strength of your evidence must scale with the unlikelihood of your claim. Without knowing the prior probability of a hypothesis being correct in a given experiment, it's difficult to say what the p-value even tells you at all.

By way of introduction, I am a physician and have been lead author on two papers podium presented at nationally recognized surgical society meetings, both of which have been selected for publication in peer reviewed surgical journals. On the way, it's no surprise that some papers aren't very useful (not generalizable to the public).  So what should you look for in a study?  Look for studies are one of two things: Randomly Controlled Trials and Meta-Analyses.  Now, read the paper, the entire paper.  If there is a word you don't know, look it up.  Many times the more reputable studies will even tell you in the body of the paper what the weaknesses are, such as: its a prospective study and therefore suffers from bias.  Look for whether or not the study is sponsored by a medical device company or pharmaceutical study and if so, beware!!  So look, don't complain about the papers - choose carefully which ones to study and review.  Use those to read their references.  Be careful about retrospective studies, studies in limited populations, studies with a small number of participants.  Good luck!!
